qas.question: There is a transitional state between one life and the next according to what branches of Buddhism?
What branch of Buddhism rejects that there is a transitional state between lives?
Passages in what teaching support the idea that the Buddha taught of a stage between lives?

answers.text: Samyutta Nikaya of the Pali Canon

qas.question: What is the state called between lives?
Which major part of Buddhism rejects bardo?
Other than Tibetan Buddhism, what other Buddhism supports bardo?
There is an intermediate state between one life and the next according to what Buddism?
What type of Theravada rejects the intermediate state idea?
Some passages of what Canon support the idea of intermediate stages?

context: According to <a0_0><a6_0><a7_0>East Asian<a6_0/> and Tibetan<a7_0/><a0_0/> Buddhism, there is an intermediate state (Tibetan "<a3_0>bardo<a3_0/>") between one life and the next. The <a8_0>orthodox<a8_0/> <a1_0><a4_0>Theravada<a4_0/><a1_0/> position rejects this; however there are passages in the <a2_0><a5_0>Samyutta Nikaya<a5_0/> of the <a9_0>Pali<a9_0/> Canon<a2_0/> that seem to lend support to the idea that the Buddha taught of an intermediate stage between one life and the next.[page needed]
